truth: You write code faster than you read it.
Most bugs come from assumptions, not syntax.
Meetings often replace actual work.
Deadlines make you cut corners.
Tests are written after the code breaks.
Code reviews find your mistakes, not theirs.
You fix the same bug multiple times.
Documentation is always outdated.
Refactoring feels good but breaks things.
You ignore warnings until they become errors.
Code comments explain the obvious.
You learn more from failures than successes.
Simple solutions are often overlooked.
Time estimates are always wrong.
You write code you don't understand.
The person who talks the most about productivity is avoiding work.
The urgent task is rarely the important one.
Most decisions are made before the meeting starts.
The plan only works until reality shows up.
Someone will always suggest rewriting everything.
The clearer your explanation, the less people listen.
The person who assigns the task will never do it.
The bigger the launch, the smaller the testing window.
You will debug something you didn't change.
Most problems are discovered by users, not systems.
The process exists because something broke once.
The fastest way to delay work is to optimize it.
Someone will ask for changes after approval.
The simplest explanation is usually ignored first.
Every shortcut adds a future meeting.
The person who wants it fastest will review it slowest.
Work expands to fill the deadline.
The issue you can't explain is the one you caused.
The longer the thread, the less anyone reads it.
The system behaves exactly as it was built, not as intended.
If everyone agrees immediately, someone misunderstood.
The more slides there are, the less clarity there is.
Most urgency is manufactured.
You will fix something that was not broken.
The person most confident is usually guessing.
The real bottleneck is usually approval.
The feature request describes a symptom, not the problem.
The more stakeholders, the slower the truth.
Someone will propose a solution before hearing the problem.
You will understand the issue right after explaining it.
Every tool promises simplicity and delivers configuration.
The system that cannot fail is already failing quietly.
Someone will ask for metrics no one plans to read.
The explanation that makes sense is the one people doubt.
The more approvals required, the less ownership exists.
The problem marked minor becomes critical.
Someone will test it in a way you never imagined.
The system is only stable because nobody touched it.
The person who wrote it is no longer here.
Every roadmap is optimistic fiction.
The more planning there is, the less clarity remains.
The real issue is always discovered last.
You will fix it after someone watches you fail.
The person who said it was easy has never done it.
The task that looks small hides the most dependencies.
The more documentation exists, the less it is trusted.
The fastest solution creates the slowest maintenance.
Someone will blame the system before reading it.
The last change is always suspected first.
You will eventually understand code you once feared.
It worked on my machine is the first stage of grief.
DevOps is just developers doing the stuff they used to hate.
A temporary fix is the most permanent thing in the codebase.
The CI pipeline only fails when you are about to leave for dinner.
YAML is just a very sensitive way to yell at a cloud.
DNS is always the prime suspect, even when it isn't.
There is no 'Cloud,' just someone else's computer on fire.
Automating a mess just makes the mess happen faster.
Senior developers are just junior developers who have broken more things.
The 'Force Push' is the 'I give up' of version control.
Microservices turn your code problems into networking problems.
A 'Quick Sync' is never quick.
Deleting code is more satisfying than writing it.
Legacy code is just code that actually makes the company money.
The environment you didn't test is the one where the bug lives.
Dark mode is the only true way to write code.
Naming things is 90% of the difficulty of engineering.
Regex is a way to solve one problem by creating two more.
The louder the server fan, the closer you are to a promotion.
Kubernetes is Greek for 'I have too much free time'.
A deployment at 4:55 PM on a Friday is a cry for help.
Containers only solve the problem of it working on your machine.
Serverless just means the server is someone else's problem.
The 'Dev' in DevOps finishes in a week; the 'Ops' takes a lifetime.
Your 'Quick Fix' is the root cause of next month's outage.
Automated tests are great until you have to maintain the tests.
Technical debt is like a credit card: eventually, you hit the limit.
The person who broke the build is usually the one who left for lunch.
Microservices are just a way to have 50 small outages instead of one big one.
The README is the first thing people ignore and the last thing they update.
Everything is a 'High Priority' until the developer asks for a specification.
The bug you can't reproduce in Staging is currently destroying Production.
Logging everything is the same as logging nothing.
Software estimation is just professional guessing under pressure.
Cloud costs only go one way: up.
A junior dev writes complex code; a senior dev writes simple code.
Git rebase is for people who want to lie about how messy their work was.
The most dangerous command is 'sudo' followed by 'I think this might work'.
Monitoring tells you it's broken; Observability tells you why you're crying.
The staging environment is just a more expensive version of 'not production'.
If you don't have a test environment, you have a production environment where you test.
The best way to get an answer on Slack is to post the wrong solution.
Scalability is what you worry about when you should be worrying about usability.
Agile is just doing the wrong thing in two-week intervals.
A database is a place where data goes to be forgotten.
The person who says 'itâ€™s just a configuration change' is about to cause an outage.
Legacy systems are the only ones that actually work.
A firewall is a device that blocks the traffic you actually need.
Cache invalidation is the second hardest problem; naming things is still first.
Coffee is the fuel that converts tickets into technical debt.
